questions.text: The flexion point in a ventouse delivery is located at which of the following positions on the fetal head?

options.label: A
options.text: 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle

options.label: B
options.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: C
options.text: 6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: D
options.text: Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.correct_answer: B. 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Samter's triad?

options.label: A
options.text: It is only triggered by aspirin.

options.label: B
options.text: Other NSAIDs with COX-1 blocking ability can also trigger symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: It is characterized by asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is only triggered by aspirin.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 

Other Name

Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD)
Key Characteristics
  • Asthma
  • Nasal polyps
  • Sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs with COX-1 inhibition
Triggering Agents Aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, such as ibuprofen and naproxen
Pathophysiology Overproduction of leukotrienes due to the inhibition of COX-1, leading to inflammation and respiratory symptoms
Common Symptoms
  • Worsening of asthma
  • Nasal congestion and sinusitis
  • Recurrence of nasal polyps
  • Respiratory distress after NSAID ingestion
Management
  • Avoidance of aspirin and COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs
  • Leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast)
  • Desensitization therapy

questions.text: Sour taste is perceived by which receptors?

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Cysto-ureth

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with jaundice, fatigue, muscle stiffness, tremors, behavioral changes, hepatosplenomegaly, and Kayser-Fleischer rings. Which test is definitive for the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

Gene Affected

ATP7B gene mutation on chromosome 13.(Option D)

Pathophysiology
  • Defective copper transport leads to:
  • Decreased copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin.
  • Impaired biliary excretion of copper.
  • Copper accumulates in the liver, spills into the bloodstream, and deposits in various tissues.

Clinical Features

Hepatic
  • Acute hepatitis
  • Chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)
  • Fulminant hepatic failure

Neurological
  • Dysarthria
  • Movement disorders (tremors, dystonia, chorea)
  • Rigidity, bradykinesia

Psychiatric
  • Depression, irritability, or psychosis
  • Cognitive decline

Ophthalmological
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings (golden-brown ring at the corneal margin due to copper deposition) in slit lamp examination (Option D)
  • Sunflower cataracts (less common)

Diagnosis

Biochemical
  • Gold standard: Elevated hepatic copper content on liver biopsy (>250 µg/g dry weight) (Option C)
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin (<20 mg/dL) (Option B)
  • Elevated 24-hour urinary copper excretion (>100 µg/day) (Option A)

Imaging

Brain MRI: Hyperintensities in basal ganglia (e.g., "face of the giant panda" sign in the midbrain)

Treatment

Copper Chelation

D-Penicillamine (binds and increases urinary copper excretion)

Copper Absorption Blockers

Zinc salts: Compete with copper absorption in the gut

Dietary

Low-copper diet (avoid shellfish, nuts, chocolate, liver)

Liver Transplant

For severe liver failure or unresponsive cases

questions.text: Patient is having a headache and confusion. A brain tumor diagnosis is made. Family history reveals brain and kidney tumors. Choose the correct option:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - VHL

Condition

VHL syndrome

Key Features

Brain tumors (hemangioblastomas), kidney tumors (renal cell carcinoma), pheochromocytomas

Diagnosis

Confirmed by genetic testing for VHL gene mutations and imaging studies for tumors

Distinguishing Factors

Presence of both brain and kidney tumors aligns with VHL syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of “feeling tensed” along with an upset stomach, diarrhea, and heartburn. She mentions that her family members also experience similar symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ The patient has a long-standing history of tension (anxiety), gastrointestinal symptoms (upset stomach, diarrhea, heartburn), and a family history of similar symptoms. This suggests a diagnosis of anxiety-related disorder or somatization with physical manifestations.
  • ↳ The patient has a long-standing history of tension (anxiety), gastrointestinal symptoms (upset stomach, diarrhea, heartburn), and a family history of similar symptoms. This suggests a diagnosis of anxiety-related disorder or somatization with physical manifestations.
  • ↳ anxiety-related disorder or somatization
  • ↳ Tingling at extremities (paresthesia) is a common somatic symptom associated with anxiety or panic disorder.
  • ↳ Tingling at extremities (paresthesia) is a common somatic symptom associated with anxiety or panic disorder.
  • ↳ Neologisms and hallucinations are features of psychotic disorders, which are not suggested here.
  • ↳ Neologisms and hallucinations are features of psychotic disorders, which are not suggested here.
  • ↳ Idea of reference is a delusional symptom seen in schizophrenia or related psychotic disorders, which is unlikely given the presentation.
  • ↳ Idea of reference is a delusional symptom seen in schizophrenia or related psychotic disorders, which is unlikely given the presentation.
  • ↳ Symptom Association Explanation Tingling at extremities Anxiety and somatic symptoms Common physical manifestation of anxiety or hyperventilation Neologisms Psychotic disorders (schizophrenia) Not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders Hallucinations Psychotic disorders Not present in anxiety disorders Idea of reference Delusional symptom in schizophrenia Not consistent with anxiety or somatic complaints
  • ↳ Symptom Association Explanation
  • ↳ Symptom
  • ↳ Association
  • ↳ Explanation
  • ↳ Tingling at extremities Anxiety and somatic symptoms Common physical manifestation of anxiety or hyperventilation
  • ↳ Tingling at extremities
  • ↳ Anxiety and somatic symptoms
  • ↳ Common physical manifestation of anxiety or hyperventilation
  • ↳ Neologisms Psychotic disorders (schizophrenia) Not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders
  • ↳ Neologisms
  • ↳ Psychotic disorders (schizophrenia)
  • ↳ Not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders
  • ↳ Hallucinations Psychotic disorders Not present in anxiety disorders
  • ↳ Hallucinations
  • ↳ Psychotic disorders
  • ↳ Not present in anxiety disorders
  • ↳ Idea of reference Delusional symptom in schizophrenia Not consistent with anxiety or somatic complaints
  • ↳ Idea of reference
  • ↳ Delusional symptom in schizophrenia
  • ↳ Not consistent with anxiety or somatic complaints
  • ↳ Neologisms (Option A): Incorrect because neologisms are made-up words seen in schizophrenia, not anxiety disorders.
  • ↳ Hallucinations (Option C): Incorrect because hallucinations are not features of anxiety disorders.
  • ↳ Idea of reference (Option D): Incorrect because this is a psychotic symptom not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders.

Symptom Association Explanation
Tingling at extremities Anxiety and somatic symptoms Common physical manifestation of anxiety or hyperventilation
Neologisms Psychotic disorders (schizophrenia) Not typical in anxiety or somatic symptom disorders
Hallucinations Psychotic disorders Not present in anxiety disorders
Idea of reference Delusional symptom in schizophrenia Not consistent with anxiety or somatic complaints

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and difficulty with horizontal eye movements. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following syndromes is most consistent with these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Millard-Gu

Condition

Millard-Gubler syndrome

Key Clinical Features

Contralateral hemiplegia (due to corticospinal tract involvement), ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy (resulting in facial paralysis and gaze palsy)

Anatomical Location

Lesion in the ventral pons

Differential Diagnosis

Distinguished from other brainstem syndromes like Foville (involves more extensive gaze palsy), Benedict’s (midbrain involvement), and Wallenberg (lateral medullary syndrome)

Rationale

The clinical features of contralateral hemiplegia with ipsilateral CN VI and VII palsy are classic for Millard-Gubler syndrome due to a ventral pontine lesion.

questions.text: A patient with a history of Wilson's disease presents with neurological manifestations. Which of the following is the best diagnostic modality?
questions.correct_answer: C. Hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Hepatic parench

Condition

Wilson's Disease

Key Diagnostic Modality

Hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper

Associated Tests

Serum ceruloplasmin (low), urinary copper excretion (high), Kayser-Fleischer rings (ophthalmic exam)

Rationale for Diagnosis

Hepatic copper concentration is the gold standard for diagnosis, especially in patients with neurological symptoms.

Differential Diagnosis

Differentiated from other causes of liver disease and neurological disorders by the combination of clinical, biochemical, and histological findings.

Treatment Implications

Early diagnosis is crucial for the initiation of chelation therapy to prevent further copper accumulation and damage.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with hypopigmented nodular lesions with anethesia over arm with ulnar nerve involvement underwent a biopsy and intradermal antigen test. Based on the image, which statement regarding the condition is most accurate?

options.label: B
options.text: Lepromatous leprosy with a positive antigen test

options.label: C
options.text: Erythema nodosum leprosum with a negative antigen test

options.label: D
options.text: Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test

questions.correct_answer: D. Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test
questions.explanation:
Feature Description
Skin lesions Numerous, symmetric, poorly defined, nodular or macular
Sensory loss Late, diffuse
Nerve involvement Multiple nerves, symmetrically
Immune response Weak or absent cell-mediated immunity (CMI)
Lepromin (Mitsuda) test Negative (due to poor CMI)
Bacillary load High
Histopathology Numerous acid-fast bacilli, foamy macrophages

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of anemia, depigmented hair, bleeding gums, and diffuse hair loss. Which of the following mineral deficiencies is most likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - C

Condition

Copper Deficiency

Key Clinical Features

Anemia, depigmented hair, bleeding gums, diffuse hair loss

Associated Symptoms

Neurological symptoms (ataxia, neuropathy), osteoporosis

Anatomical/Physiological Role

Copper is essential for iron metabolism, melanin production, and collagen synthesis.

Differential Diagnosis

Distinguished from iron, fluoride, and zinc deficiencies by the presence of specific symptoms such as depigmented hair and bleeding gums.

Rationale

The combination of anemia, depigmented hair, and bleeding gums is characteristic of copper deficiency, as copper is crucial for several enzymatic functions.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypotension, hyponatremia and blackening of the knuckles and perioral area. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Addison’s D

Symptoms

Hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperpigmentation (knuckles, perioral)

Cause

Primary adrenal insufficiency (low cortisol and aldosterone)

Pathophysiology

Elevated ACTH due to low cortisol levels leads to increased melanin production

Lab Findings

Low sodium, high potassium, low cortisol, high ACTH

Management

Corticosteroid replacement therapy (hydrocortisone, fludrocortisone)
